                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Take the arithmetic progression "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"101k, 102k, \ldots, 199k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which has 99 terms. We wish to find a "},{"type":"text","text":"k","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":" such that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"102k, 102k, \ldots, 198k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are powers of positive integers, while 101k and 199k aren't. To be specific, we let "},{"type":"text","text":"S","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":" denote the set of primes < 198 and excluding 101, then pick k of the form: "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" k =\prod_{p \in S} p^{m_p} = 2^{m_2} \times 3^{m_3} \times 5^{m_5} \times\ldots "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"for suitable non-negative integers "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m_2, m_3, m_5, m_7, \ldots"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Pick any distinct primes "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"q_{102}, q_{103}, \ldots, q_{198}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"; for every prime "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p\in S"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" solve the following congruences:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \begin{aligned} m_p + \nu(102, p) &\equiv 0 \pmod {q_{102}}, \\
m_p + \nu(103, p) &\equiv 0 \pmod {q_{103}},\\
&\vdots \\
m_p + \nu(198, p) &\equiv 0 \pmod {q_{198}}. \end{aligned} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Here, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\nu(n, p)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the largest "},{"type":"text","text":"j","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":" such that  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p^j | n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Note that since all prime factors of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"102, \ldots, 198"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" lie in S, we have: "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 102 = \prod_{p\in S} p^{\nu(102, p)}, \ 103 = \prod_{p\in S} p^{\nu(103, p)}, \ \ldots, \ 198 = \prod_{p\in S} p^{\nu(198, p)}. "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"By Chinese Remainder Theorem, there's a solution for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m_p"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" in the above congruences. Since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k =\prod_{p \in S} p^{m_p}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", we see that:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 102k = \prod_{p\in S} p^{\nu(102, p)} p^{m_p} = \prod_{p\in S} p^{m_p + \nu(102, p)} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"is a "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"q_{102}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"-th power, and likewise for each of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"i = 103, \ldots, 198"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", the multiple "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"ik"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"q_i"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"-th power. Thus, we have a sequence which satisfies (1)."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This sequence clearly satisfies (2) as well since 101 and 199 are prime and k is not a multiple of 101 or 199."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

I had the exact idea that if you have a small sequence that's all powers then multiplying it the next item by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a^{\frac{M+1}{k+1}}|]"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" gives you a longer sequence of all powers. But when I tried it out on a numeric example I forgot to start with a sequence of powers and it didn't work so I moved onto other ideas.

                                            He chose the sequence because it works. See the above discussion for what are the crucial aspects of the sequence that works."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Here is a simpler way of understanding the proof, which uses very similar idea. Starting with the sequence "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"101, 102, \ldots , 199 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (where once again the important criterion is that both 101 and 199 are prime), we want to inductively make each term (from the second) a power."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Base step: Starting with the second, we multiply the sequence by 102, which makes the second term "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"102^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which is a power."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Induction step: Let the terms "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" a_2, a_3, \ldots a_k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be powers. Let the LCM of the exponents be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"M"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Then, multiplying the entire sequence by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" a_{k+1}^{M+1} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" makes all the terms "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a_2, \ldots a_{k+1} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" a power term."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hence, it is possible to make "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" a_2, a_3, \ldots a_{98} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" all powers. Now, we check that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a_1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (respectively  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a_{99}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":") is not a power. This is because it is a multiple of 101 (resp 199), but not "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"101^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (resp "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"199^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ).

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

Clearly, if we look at the occurrence pattern of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"14"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", we see that if the power of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"14"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is even, the unit's digit is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and if the power is odd, the unit's digit is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"From the question, the power of the first base "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"14"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", is clearly even. So, the unit's digit will definitely be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"14 \uparrow\uparrow 14 = 14^{14 \uparrow\uparrow 13}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The exponent is thus "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"14^a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is an integer greater than 1. Hence, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"14^a = 0 \mod 4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"14^{14^a} \mod 10 = 4^4 \mod 10 = \boxed{6}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So now , "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\tau_{ext} = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So no External torque is acting on it. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So it doesnt mean that No "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"F_{ext}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is acting on it, As "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\tau_{ext} = F_{ext} .r"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So If r=0 then also "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\tau_{ext} = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"And If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"F_{ext} = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" then also "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\tau_{ext} = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"And Linear momentum is conserved when "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"F_{ext} = 0 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So it may or may not be,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So we cannot determine it by this statement."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hence answer is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{\text{Cannot be determined}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

title: 1, 4 or 7?
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"You and a friend play a game where you start with a pile of 100 stones."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"You alternate turns, and each turn you can take 1, 4 or 7 stones."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The player that takes the last stone (leaving nothing in the pile) wins!"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Which player can guarantee a win?"}]}]}

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The first player can take 4 stones, leaving 96 in the pile, which divides evenly by 8.  "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"After that if the other player takes "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" stones, the first player takes "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"8-n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" stones, leaving the pile with a number that is again divisible by 8."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This continues until the pile contains 0 stones, at which point the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{\text{player that went first}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" has won."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Definitely more interesting!  "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I suppose the strategy then would be to leave the other player with a number of stones in the pile divisible by 14.  I wonder if their are distributions where the strategy is more complex than "leaving the other player with a pile divisible by n". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For example, 2, 5, and 7...  I think that perhaps the best either player could do then is force a draw if the original pile contains more than 11 stones.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            The option of "neither player" would be interesting if it was possible for the game to not end, e.g. if we could only take stones of sizes 4, 7, 10, which leaves the possibility of having 1/2/3 stones left behind.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The first player can also win by first taking 7 stones. Then on each set of turns forcing that 8 stones be removed until they are left with 5 stones and it is the second player's turn."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Whether he takes 1 or 4 the first player can do the opposite and gets the last stone."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Taking 1 stone on the first move would be a mistake.  I will leave it to the reader to see a winning strategy for the second player in that case."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

To find answer let's generalise the whole thing.
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sin(x)=x\prod_{n=1}^∞ (1-\frac{x^2}{π^2n^2}) "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Taking log on both sides and Differentiating respect to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" gives us 
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\cot(x)= \dfrac{1}{x} +\sum_{n=1}^∞ \dfrac{1}{x+nπ} +\sum_{n=1}^∞ \dfrac{1}{x-nπ} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\cot(x)= \sum_{n=-∞}^∞ \dfrac{1}{nπ+x} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Differentiating respect to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" again gives "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"-\dfrac{1}{\sin^2(x)} = -\sum_{n=-∞}^∞ \dfrac{1}{(nπ+x)^2} \implies \sum_{n=-∞}^∞ \dfrac{1}{(nπ+x)^2}=\dfrac{1}{\sin^2(x)}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" 
take "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=\dfrac{1}{π}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" 
It gives "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\cdots+\dfrac{1}{(1-2π^2)^2}+\dfrac{1}{(1-π^2)^2} +1 +\dfrac{1}{(1+π^2)^2}+\dfrac{1}{(1+2π^2)^2} +\dfrac{1}{(1+3π^2)^2}+\cdots=\dfrac{1}{π^2 \sin^2(\frac{1}{π})}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Answer is"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \boxed{a=1}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This\quad figure\quad shows\quad the\quad position\quad of\quad the\quad block\quad after\quad a\\ neglegible\quad time\quad \Delta .\\ \\ Since\quad the\quad velocity\quad of\quad the\quad rope\quad is\quad V,\quad its\quad length\quad\\ on\quad the\quad left\quad  side\quad of\quad the\quad pulley\quad changes\quad by\quad \Delta .V\quad in\quad \Delta \quad time.\\ So\quad AB=\Delta .V\qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad  \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \left( 1 \right) \\ \\ AC\quad is\quad the\quad displacement\quad covered\quad in\quad \Delta \quad time\quad by\quad the\quad block.\\ \\ So,\quad AC=\Delta .U\quad (Where\quad U\quad is\quad the\quad velocity\quad of\quad the\quad block)\quad \quad \quad \quad \quad \quad \quad \quad  \quad \quad \quad \quad \left( 2 \right) \\ By\quad simple\quad trigo\quad we\quad can\quad see\quad that\quad AC=AB\csc { \theta  } \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \left( 3 \right) \\ \\ Using\quad \left( 1 \right) ,\left( 2 \right) \quad and\quad \left( 3 \right) ,\quad we\quad get\\ \Delta .U=\Delta .V\csc { \theta  } \\ So\quad U=V\csc { \theta  } \\ So\quad U=150\times 2=300"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"
